children.subject:
<md>Are there certain classes that make 120A more manageable? I am thinking of taking it with only Chem 1A/1B background, but is Chem 15 or Chem 4B actually a hard prereq instead of just 1B? Or do Math 110 or Chem 104A help?

I know this is kind of off-topic, but chemistry doesn't have an advising Piazza -- I'm kind of starved for knowledge here.</md>

Chem major here. The College of Chemistry has a Piazza now: COC 101. 

Chem 104A is totally different from 120A — 104A is about inorganic chemistry. Many chem majors actually take 120A alongside organic as sophomores, with only 4A/4B. From what I've heard, the most important prereq for 120A is linear algebra. That's why I'm considering chem 120A and ee 127 might make sense to take together...
Oh also: from what I've heard, 110 might be helpful for the linear algebra in 120A.

The most important prereq is Math 54. You actually don't need 104A for 120A (a lot of chem majors take 120A before 104A too, and some chem bio/chemE majors take 120A without any of the 104 series). 

Math 110 might help, though it's a bit too much imo for 120A. I don't recommend taking 110 just to do better on 120A, unless QM is your interest/research field.

@Gear 

My advice is to take one or the other, but not together. If you're doing 127 to prepare for 120A, try doing it a semester before. Conversely, if you want to do well in 127, do 120A first.
imo 170 wasn't too bad, the material can be kind of tricky but the weekly psets + final project did not take much time

Hmm funny I found chem 120A not too difficult as an engineer.  All my pure chemistry (non-double majors) friends did have a lot of trouble in it however, from the math (and I guess general QM) .  I'd suggest taking it earlier while your mathematical background in linear algebra is still good; I'll admit if I were to take it again, I'd have difficulties since I haven't touched linear algebra since! It is definitively imo far easier than EECS 127 and 170 (both of which I dropped), since in 120A they do try to focus on more high-level concepts than the nitty-gritty math compared to physics 137B.   I will say that even though I am now an RF engineer as a grad student, 120A was one of my favorite classes as an undergrad, so do give it a shot!

Chem 104A is pretty easy, but the professors tend to be awful (unless Prof John Arnold is teaching who is amazing).  Cheers!

Chem 120A is very, very hard, and if you're taking it for a good grade, I'd say it's a very high workload class despite being 3 units. From a friend that took 127, this is also a pretty time-consuming class on the math side. I don't think it's good to take 120A and 127 together as they're both kind of math-intensive, along with another tech. But if you have a good background in linear algebra, you can probably pull it off. 

Don't know much about CS 170, someone else can comment on that.

Physics 137A has much more math. They go over more derivations for example, and their psets are more math-based. 120A sometimes skips over the mathy part of QM and focuses on concepts more. They also may use more examples related to chemistry. It sometimes depends on the professor. 

If you want a very in-depth, math-heavy class about QM specifically, take Phys 137A. I would suggest 120A for any chem majors or chemE, or if you're more interested about applications of QM in chemistry than the math.

Like anon above said, if you want a more applied, general overview (and an easier class), take Chem 120A.  In 120A, practicing the underlying mathematics isn't deemed to important- instead the class goes as quickly as possible to chemical applications, such as the hydrogen atom, spin-orbit coupling, and cool things like Benzene molecular orbitals (Huckel MO theory).  137A in contrast spends the first half solving Schrodinger's equation for every type of energy structure (particle in a box, in a triangle, in a square etc etc- just doing a bunch of math with different boundary conditions) and then finishes up by deriving the closed form solution for the hydrogen atom over the course of a month (which is basically a bunch of math discovered in the 1700's).  It isn't until 137B that spin-orbit etc is reached.  I obviously preferred 120A, but the truth is that if you want to research QM/phys. chemistry, all the professors recommend taking both the chemistry and physics classes; if you just need to meet the major requirements or learn applications, then take 120A.
Any thoughts on the pros and cons of Chemistry 120A versus Physics 137A?

history.content: How does CS 170, EECS 127 and Chem 120A (quantum mechanics, comparable workload to other pset based upper div tech) sound for next spring? I'll hopefully be taking 2 other lighter electives as well.
history.subject: Schedule advice
